facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 81 of 1953 was filed under article 132(1) of the Constitution of India.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 81 of 1953. Appeal under article 132 1  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order, dated the 18th April, 1951, of the High Court of Judicature for the State of Orissa at Cuttack in Judicial Case No. 60 of 1951.

facts.text: Appeal from Judgment and Order dated 18th April 1951 of High Court of Orissa in Judicial Case No. 60 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal under article 132 1  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order, dated the 18th April, 1951, of the High Court of Judicature for the State of Orissa at Cuttack in Judicial Case No. 60 of 1951.

facts.text: Appellant is a legal practitioner residing within Kendrapara Municipality practising as mukhtar in criminal and revenue courts.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BHAGWATI J.-The appellant who is a legal practitioner residing within the limits of the Kendrapara Municipality and practising as a mukhtar in the criminal and the revenue Courts there filed his numberination paper for election as a Councillor of the Municipality on the 15th March, 1951.

facts.text: Appellant filed nomination paper for election as Councillor of Kendrapara Municipality on 15th March 1951.

anchor.surface_text: practising as a mukhtar in the criminal and the revenue Courts there filed his numberination paper for election as a Councillor of the Municipality on the 15th March, 1951.

facts.text: Nomination paper rejected by Election Officer on 25th March 1951 on ground that appellant employed as legal practitioner against Municipality in case US 198 of Bihar and Orissa Municipal Act pending in Sub-Divisional Magistrate Court.

anchor.surface_text: That numberination paper was rejected by the Election Officer on the 25th March, 1951, on the ground that he was employed as a legal practitioner against the Municipality in a case U S 198 of the Bihar and Orissa Municipal Act which was pending in the Sub-Divisional Magistrate Court.

facts.text: Appellant filed petition before High Court of Orissa on 4th April 1951 under article 226 praying for writ of prohibition against State Government and Election Officer.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then filed on the 4th April, 1951, a petition before the High Court of Orissa under article 226 of the Constitution praying that a writ or order of prohibition be issued to the State Government and the Election Officer restraining them from holding the election to the Kendrapara Municipality under the Orissa Municipal Act, 1950 or the Municipal Election Rules, 1950.

facts.text: High Court rejected petition but granted certificate under article 132(1) for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: This petition was rejected by the High Court but the High Court granted the appellant a certificate under article 132 1  of the Constitution for leave to appeal to this Court.

facts.text: Orissa Municipal Act 1950 (Orissa Act 23 of 1950) received assent of Governor on 7th November 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The Orissa Municipal Act, 1950  Orissa Act 23 of 1950  was passed by the local Legislature and received the assent of the Governor on the 7th November, 1950, and was published in the official gazette on the 11th November, 1950.

facts.text: Orissa Municipal Act 1950 published in official gazette on 11th November 1950.

anchor.surface_text: and received the assent of the Governor on the 7th November, 1950, and was published in the official gazette on the 11th November, 1950.

facts.text: Section 16 of Orissa Municipal Act 1950 prescribes disqualification for candidates employed as paid legal practitioner on behalf of or against the Municipality.

anchor.surface_text: Section 16 of the Act prescribes the disqualifications of candidates for election and provides No person shall be qualified for election to a seat in a Municipality, if such person  ix   is employed as a paid legal practitioner on behalf of the Municipality or as legal practitioner against the Municipality

facts.text: Secretary to Government, Local Self-Government Department addressed letter No. 1336/L.S.G. to all District Magistrates on 11th November 1950 intimating general elections in 12 municipalities including Kendrapara on adult suffrage.

anchor.surface_text: On the 11th November, 1950, the Secretary to the Government, Local Self-Government Department addressed to all District Magistrates of the State letter No. 1336/L.S.G. intimating that the Government had decided that general elections should be held on the basis of adult suffrage as provided in the Act in 12 Municipalities including the Kendrapara Municipality.

facts.text: Notification No. 2015 L.S.G. issued on 13th December 1950 under section 13 read with section 1(5) fixing 1st March 1950 as relevant date for voters' residential qualification.

anchor.surface_text: Notification No. 2015 L.S.G. was issued on the 13th December, 1950, under section 13 read with section 1  5  of the Act fixing- the 1st day of March, 1950, as the relevant date for voters in the election as regards their residential qualification in the Municipality.

facts.text: Notification No. 65 L.S.G. issued on 4th January 1951 publishing Municipal Election Rules 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Notification No. 65 L.S.G. issued on the 4th January, 1951, published rules made in exercise of the powers companyferred by clauses  1  and  2  of sub-section  2  of section 387 of the Act called the Municipal Election Rules, 1950.

facts.text: Redistribution of wards by Notification No. 167 L.S.G. dated 10th January 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Redistribution of wards was effected by Notification No. 167 L.S.G. dated the 10th January, 1951, and two Notifications Nos. 519 and 521 L.S.G. were issued on the 24th January, 1951, fixing 1007 the numbers of Councillors and of the reserved seats for each Municipality.

facts.text: Notifications Nos. 519 and 521 L.S.G. issued on 24th January 1951 fixing numbers of Councillors and reserved seats.

anchor.surface_text: dated the 10th January, 1951, and two Notifications Nos. 519 and 521 L.S.G. were issued on the 24th January, 1951, fixing 1007 the numbers of Councillors and of the reserved seats for each Municipality.

facts.text: 15th March 1951 fixed as date for filing nominations.

anchor.surface_text: The 15th March, 1951, was fixed as the date for filing the numberinations and the 25th March, 1951, for scrutiny of numberination papers.

facts.text: 25th March 1951 fixed for scrutiny of nomination papers.

anchor.surface_text: filing the numberinations and the 25th March, 1951, for scrutiny of numberination papers. The 20th April, 1951, was the date fixed for the holding of the election.

facts.text: 20th April 1951 fixed as date for holding election.

anchor.surface_text: the 25th March, 1951, for scrutiny of numberination papers. The 20th April, 1951, was the date fixed for the holding of the election.

facts.text: Orissa Municipal Act extended to Kendrapara Municipality on 15th April 1951 by notification under section 1(3).

anchor.surface_text: All these steps were taken by the Government in anticipation acting under the powers reserved under section 1  5  of the Act and it was only on the 15th April, 1951, that the Act was extended to the Kendrapara Municipality by a numberification under section 1  3  of the Act.

facts.text: Appellant contended that Act had not come into operation in Kendrapara till 15th April 1951 so disqualification not applicable on 15th March 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companytended  1  that the Act had number companye into operation in the Kendrapara Municipality till the 15th April, 1951, that the disqualification- prescribed by section 16 1   ix  companyld number companysequently have been incurred by him on the 15th March, 1951, when he filed his numberination paper,

facts.text: Appellant contended that section 16(1)(ix) violated fundamental rights under article 14 and 19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: that in any event the disqualification prescribed under section 16 1   ix  of the Act violated his fundamentals rights guaranteed under article 14 and article 19 1   g  of the Constitution.

facts.text: High Court negatived both contentions of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Both these companytentions were in our opinion rightly negatived by the High Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on 25th November 1954 by BHAGWATI J.

anchor.surface_text: Porus A. Mehta and P. g. Gokhale for the respondent. 1954. November 25. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BHAGWATI J.-The appellant who is a legal practitioner residing within the limits of the Kendrapara Municipality

facts.text: Section 1(5) of Act provides elections can be held after assent but take effect on coming into force.

anchor.surface_text: Section 1  5  of the Act in express terms provides that after the Act has received the assent of the Governor elections companyld be held under the Act but were only to take effect on the Act companying into force,

anchor.surface_text: Article 14 forbids class legislation but does not forbid reasonable classification for the purposes of legislation. That classification however cannot be arbitrary but must rest upon some real and substantial distinction bearing a reasonable and just relation to the things in respect of which the classification is made. In other words the classification must have a reasonable relation to the object or the purpose sought to be achieved by the impugned legislation.

concepts.interpretation: Applied to uphold classification of legal practitioners employed against/for Municipality as having rational nexus to purity of public life and avoiding conflict of interest/duty

issues.text: Whether the Orissa Municipal Act, 1950 had come into operation in the Kendrapara Municipality till the 15th April, 1951 such that the disqualification under section 16(1)(ix) applied to the appellant's nomination paper filed on the 15th March, 1951 and the rejection thereof was legal

anchor.surface_text: The appellant contended  1  that the Act had not come into operation in the Kendrapara Municipality till the 15th April, 1951, that the disqualification prescribed by section 16 1   ix  could consequently have been incurred by him on the 15th March, 1951, when he filed his nomination paper, that the rejection of his nomination paper therefore on that ground by the Election Officer on the 25th March, 1951,

issues.text: Whether the disqualification prescribed under section 16(1)(ix) of the Orissa Municipal Act, 1950 violated the appellant's fundamental rights under article 14 and article 19(1)(g) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: that in any event the disqualification prescribed under section 16 1   ix  of the Act violated his fundamental rights guaranteed under article 14 and article 19 1   g  of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: The Orissa Municipal Act, 1950 had not come into operation in the Kendrapara Municipality till the 15th April, 1951, so the disqualification under section 16(1)(ix) could not have been incurred on the 15th March, 1951 when nomination paper was filed and its rejection was illegal

anchor.surface_text: The appellant contended 1 that the Act had not come into operation in the Kendrapara Municipality till the 15th April, 1951, that the disqualification prescribed by section 16 1 ix could consequently have been incurred by him on the 15th March, 1951, when he filed his nomination paper, that the rejection of his nomination paper therefore on that ground by the Election Officer on the 25th March, 1951,

arguments.court_reasoning: Classification reasonable under Art 14 with nexus to purity of public life; no fundamental right to contest election under Art 19(1)(g), disqualification is reasonable restriction under Art 19(5)

arguments.claim: Appellant disqualified under section 16(1)(ix) as employed as legal practitioner against the Municipality in pending case under Bihar and Orissa Municipal Act

anchor.surface_text: That nomination paper was rejected by the Election Officer on the 25th March, 1951, on the ground that he was employed as a legal practitioner against the Municipality in a case U S 198 of the Bihar and Orissa Municipal Act which was pending in the Sub-Divisional Magistrate Court.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: held under the Act but were only to take effect on the Act companying into force, which means the companying into force of the Act in such area or are

arguments.court_reasoning: Section 1(5) validates application of disqualification as part of preliminary steps for election

arguments.claim: Section 1(5) expressly provides that elections may be held under the Act after Governor's assent but take effect on coming into force, authorizing all preliminary steps including scrutiny of nominations and application of disqualifications

anchor.surface_text: Both these contentions were in our opinion rightly negatived by the High Court. Section 1 5 of the Act in express terms provides that after the Act has received the assent of the Governor elections could be held under the Act but were only to take effect on the Act coming into force, which means the coming into force of the Act in such area or areas on such date or dates which the State Government might appoint from time to time under section 1 3 of the Act.

arguments.claim: Disqualification of paid legal practitioners for or against Municipality is reasonable classification under Article 14 as it bears rational relation to object of ensuring purity of public life by avoiding conflict between interest and duty

anchor.surface_text: Article 14 forbids class legislation but does not forbid reasonable classification for the purposes of legislation. That classification however cannot be arbitrary but must rest upon some real and substantial distinction bearing a reasonable and just relation to the things in respect of which the classification is made.

arguments.claim: Disqualification does not violate Article 19(1)(g) as there is no fundamental right to stand for election and any restriction on practice of profession is reasonable under Article 19(5) in interests of general public

anchor.surface_text: The right of the appellant to practise the profession of law guaranteed by article 19 1 g cannot be said to have been violated, because in laying down the disqualification in section 16 1 ix of the Act the Legislature does not prevent him from practising his profession of law but it only lays down that if he wants to stand as a candidate for election he shall not either be employed as a paid legal practitioner on behalf of the municipality or act as a legal practitioner against the Municipality.

arguments.claim: Disqualification is discriminatory under Article 14 because other categories with potential conflict of interest and duty such as clients litigating against Municipality are not disqualified

anchor.surface_text: It was however urged that besides this category there are also other categories where there would be a possibility of conflict between interest and duty and that in so far as they were not covered by the disqualifications prescribed by section 16 1 of the Act the provision disqualifying the category to which the appellant belonged was discriminatory.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: loyed as a paid legal practi- tioner on behalf of

arguments.court_reasoning: Legislature need not embrace all possible categories for the object; omission of some does not make it discriminatory

arguments.claim: Preliminary steps taken before Act came into force in area are validated by section 23 of Orissa General Clauses Act

anchor.surface_text: the defect could not have been cured by the provisions of section 23 of the Orissa General Clauses Act Orissa Act I of 1937 which was relied upon by the respondent.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the Municipality there is a likelihood of his misusing his position for the purposes of obtaining Municipal briefs for himself and persuading the Muni

arguments.court_reasoning: Not necessary as section 1(5) expressly validates such steps

holdings.text: Section 1(5) of the Orissa Municipal Act, 1950 expressly provides that elections could be held under the Act after assent of the Governor but take effect only on the Act coming into force, thereby validating all preliminary steps including application of disqualifications under section 16(1)(ix) before notification under section 1(3)

anchor.surface_text: Both these contentions were in our opinion rightly negatived by the High Court. Section 1 5 of the Act in express terms provides that after the Act has received the assent of the Governor elections could be held under the Act but were only to take effect on the Act coming into force, which mea

holdings.reasoning_summary: Literal interpretation of s1(5) as proviso to s1(3) effective immediately upon assent; necessary implication authorizes incidental steps like nomination scrutiny and disqualifications for elections to be feasible; s23 General Clauses Act unnecessary

holdings.text: The disqualification under section 16(1)(ix) does not violate Article 14 as it constitutes reasonable classification of paid legal practitioners for/against Municipality resting on real distinction with rational relation to object of ensuring purity of public life by avoiding conflict between interest and duty

anchor.surface_text: The contention that the disqualification prescribed in section 16 1 ix violates the fundamental rights of the appellant under article 14 and article 19 1 g is equally untenable. Article 14 forbids class legislation but does not forbid reasonable classification for the purposes of legislation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies twin test of intelligible differentia and rational nexus; classification targets direct conflict via employment/briefs against Municipality; legislature not obligated to cover every possible conflict category

holdings.text: The disqualification under section 16(1)(ix) does not violate Article 19(1)(g) as no fundamental right exists to contest municipal election and any incidental restriction on legal practice is reasonable under Article 19(5) in interests of general public and purity of public life

anchor.surface_text: It was however urged that besides this category there are also other categories where there would be a possibility of conflict between interest and duty and that in so far as they were not covered by the disqualifications prescribed by section 16 1 of the Act the provision disqualifying

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes right to practice profession from seeking elective office; disqualification requires divesting briefs only if contesting, preserving practice right; reasonable restriction saved by Art 19(5)

anchor.surface_text: Both these contentions were in our opinion rightly negatived by the High Court.

outcome.relief_summary: Both contentions of the appellant rejected; High Court order upheld, no relief to appellant
